results.title: Battle for bread
results.creator_credit: Richard De Rochemont, United Nations. Film Board and March of Time, Inc.
results.brief_description: The film stresses the importance of food in a world that has never produced enough for everyone, and describes the efforts of FAO to stimulate food production in many countries. After a preliminary survey of the food problem in war-torn countries, the film describes the working of the FAO program; agricultural machinery to China, international conferences on poison sprays for insects, the fight against animal diseases, encouragement to farmers to grow new kinds of crops.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard De Rochemont, United Nations. Film Board and March of Time, Inc.

results.title: Battered women: violence behind closed doors
results.creator_credit: J. Gary Mitchell, J Gary Mitchell Film Company and Christina Crowley
results.brief_description: Examines the problem of wife beating and points out new methods of police intervention in cases of domestic violence. Includes interviews with abusive men and victimised women, encouraging women to speak out and seek protection from violent husbands.

results.title: Bats, birds and bionics
results.creator_credit: Isaac Kleinerman, John MacDonald and Columbia Broadcasting System
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
Demonstrates the application of the principles of natural systems in living animals such as bats, rattlesnakes, frogs and rats, to engineering devices to guide blind persons, self guiding missiles, photoelectric scanners capable of distinguishing shapes and bionic computers designed to learn and to control man-like robots. Reporter: Walter Cronkite.

results.title: Batman's village
results.creator_credit: Ivor P. Kershaw and Factual Films of Australia
results.brief_description: A picturesque view of Melbourne city interspersed with factual information on its history and the key figures involved in its establishment. Inner city streets, buildings and botanical gardens are shown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ivor P. Kershaw and Factual Films of Australia

results.title: Batik
results.brief_description: A history of the Indian and Indonesian art and a demonstration by Nancy Belfer. Shows modern and traditional pieces being made. We see washing, drying and framing the cloth, the initial blocking-in of shapes, working with heated wax, the tjanting tool and the tjap, with a sequence on the actual printing and dyeing of the cloth. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Bathtime
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School, John Bird, David Atkinson and Peter Madden
results.brief_description: A humourous claymation where a woman after waking in the morning takes a bath going through her morning cleansing ritual before work. The partner only later wakes up to find the woman missing.

results.title: Bathing the patient (home care)
results.creator_credit: F.E. Brooker, Ted Nemeth Studios, United States. Office of Education. Division of Visual Aids and Marian Evans
results.brief_description: A guide to the home care of that maimed and injured loved one, recently returned from that dust-up in the Pacific. Solemn tone betrays not the least sympathy for the invalided one. In the absence of emotion, the domestic environment becomes a place of chilling austerity. Dutiful wife seeming resigned to her fate as resentful attendant. Frightening for its utilitarian ommissions. United States Office of Education training film for use in the instruction of professional nurses.

results.title: Bathing the bed patient
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Care of the sick and injured”.
Procedure for making a bed with a minimum of disturbance to the patient. Also demonstrates the proper method of washing the patient with as much comfort as posible.

results.title: Bass on titles
results.creator_credit: Pyramid Films and Saul Bass Films
results.brief_description: This film features American film producer Saul Bass discussing the evolution of title sequences that he has designed for feature films. He demonstrates how he translates the themes of major motion pictures into graphic visual animation. Sequences from films include: ‘The Man with the golden arm’, ‘West side story’, ‘It’s a mad, mad, mad world’ and ‘Walk on the wild side’, among others. Suitable for Upper Secondary-Tertiary level students. No other credits available.
